titleStmt.title: I heat the hot cores
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript between 1850 and 1855, as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. Words and imagery from the manuscript are similar to lines in the first poem of that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself." The manuscript has been pasted down, so an image of the back of the leaf is unavailable.

note.p: Words and imagery from this manuscript are similar to language in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, later titled "Song of Myself": "the suns I see and the suns I cannot see are in their place" and "And of the threads that connected the stars—and of wombs, and of the fatherstuff" (1855, pp. 24, 29).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: I heat the hot cores within
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: checked and corrected file, added corresps

lg.l:
I heat the hot cores of the globe within, and fix
the central point of the cores

And I carry the straight threads f thence thence to the
sun and to distant unseen suns.—
